SEG.ORIGINAL_TEXT: South Carolina House Approves Bill to Remove Confederate Flag
South Carolina House Approves Bill to Remove Confederate Flag
The South Carolina House has approved a bill to remove the Confederate flag from the Statehouse grounds, and the flag could be removed within days.
The move early Thursday came after more than 13 hours of debate.
The House approved the Senate bill by more than a two-thirds margin. The bill now heads to the desk of Republican Gov. Nikki Haley, who supports the measure.
Also today pigs were seen flying
150 years behind schedule, but better late than never.

Like it or not, that flag became a symbol of hatred.
The shootings were not motivated by the flag and anyone who thinks so is an idiot.
However, it does make state governments that fly it look like they support the cause of white supremacy though that isn't the intention.
Let's not discount the effect symbolism has on people.
You oppose this measure on the grounds that it is just "feel good legislation" that won't do anything about the hatred behind the shootings and you are right.
But two things make me think removing the flag from state grounds is the right thing to do:
1. If it was so innocuous, why are so many people upset about it?
2. It's not about being right, it's about doing right.
He's parading around as a White Supremacist with the Confederate flag while stomping on and burning The Stars and Stripes like the south should have won the war and will rise again.
Of course people are outraged he's burning the American flag while idolizing the Confederate one.
Like it or not, that flag became a symbol of hatred.
The shootings were not motivated by the flag and anyone who thinks so is an idiot.
However, it does make state governments that fly it look like they support the cause of white supremacy though that isn't the intention.
Let's not discount the effect symbolism has on people.
You oppose this measure on the grounds that it is just "feel good legislation" that won't do anything about the hatred behind the shootings and you are right.
But two things make me think removing the flag from state grounds is the right thing to do:
<em>1. If it was so innocuous, why are so many people upset about it?
2. It's not about being right, it's about doing right.</em>

So just because a group of people don't like something or disagree with it, It needs to go? What happened to the First Amendment? There was a Confederate flag rally not too far from me in Alcoa. One of the photos from the local newspaper showed a young man wearing a t-shirt with "KKK" on in with the Confederate flag in the letters. Does that help the confederate flag's image? NO. Do I have the right to go beat the crap out of him and rip it off his body? NO Do these knuckle heads have the right to free speech and assemble lawfully? YES. We're heading down a slippery slope when we start removing and banning things because someone gets offended or doesn't like it. I went to the Thunder Valley Nationals a couple of weeks ago. There's a big Confederate flag flying outside of the track. I didn't die because it was there and it didn't affect me in anyway from having a good time with my fellow racing enthusiasts. I saw people of every nationality and color at that race and I guarantee you, that flag was the furthest thing from their minds.
I said all that to say this: If you don't like, don't look at it.
whew... at least without the constant reminder of the "flag" all racism in South Carolina will cease to exist. Now, on to West "BY GOD" Virginia and the monuments to Grand Kleagle Byr

Who is saying you yourself or private citizens can't display the confederate battle flag?
This is and has always been about state governments flying it.
If private companies make similar decisions not to display or sell the flag, that is their right.
I don't see jackbooted thugs ripping or confiscating confederate battle flags.

They also demonstrated their interest in ending the glorification and falsification of so-called Southern "heritage", which is nothing but nostalgia for the days when a large portion of the population of the South were enslaved. That is about as worthy of nostalgia as the 3rd Reich.
